swing.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to make regular movements forwards and backwards or from one side to another while hanging from a particular point, or to make something do this
swing.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Let your arms swing as you walk.
a sign swinging in the wind
He was swinging his bag back and forth.
She swung her legs from side to side.
He marched around, swinging the gun by its handle.
swing.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to move quickly in a smooth curve in one direction, or to make something do this
swing.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: A black car swung into the drive.
Kate swung her legs out of bed.
Swinging her bag over her shoulder, she hurried on.
swing.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to move your arm or something you are holding to try and hit something
swing.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: She swung her bag at him.
Garson swung at the ball and missed.
He started swinging at me with his fists.
swing.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: if emotions or opinions swing, or if something swings them, they change quickly to the opposite of what they were
swing.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: The war had begun to swing in Britain’s favor.
His mood could swing from joy to despair.
swing.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to sit on a swing and make it move backwards and forwards by moving your legs
swing.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to arrange for something to happen, although it takes a lot of effort to do this
swing.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: We managed to swing it so that they will travel together.
swing.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a seat hanging from ropes or chains, usually used by children to play on by moving it forwards and backwards using their legs
swing.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: a curved movement made with your arm, leg etc
swing.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: He took a swing at  (=tried to hit) my head and missed.
the swing of her hips as she walked
swing.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: a noticeable change in opinions or emotions
swing.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: a big swing towards right-wing ideology
swing.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: the movement you make when you hit the ball in golf, baseball, or some other sports
swing.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: I spent months correcting my swing.
swing.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: a type of dance music played by a big band in the 1930s and 1940s that is similar to jazz
swing.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to change from one level, rate, or position to another so that a situation is the opposite of what it was before
swing.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: If the economy swings from recession into recovery, the banks’ problems will ease significantly.
Prices swung over a wide range, dropping in early trading to $1,383 before recovering.
swing.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: a sudden and noticeable change in the level, rate, or position of something
swing.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: Changes in revenue could produce largeearnings swings.
Investor uncertainty is likely to translate intoprice swings.
